title: This new elaborate way of saying "I'm feeding/giving up" needs to be eradicated.
body:
This Disconunu/Disco whomever is ridiculous and needs to stop. I don't care if you want to have fun in a normal with people who agree to let you troll, but when you do this in a ranked you need to be punished or suspended from ranked for a bit. It's not fair that someone has to dodge or are forced to play the game if you can't due to promos or whatever else. Blacked out the kids name because rules, if a red wants the name or if there's anyway I can send in the unedited screenshot let me know.

UPDATE: Support has replied to my ticket and are investigating the issue, hopefully we won't have to worry about this guy or anyone else who trolls deliberately in ranked.

you ever play a league of legends game? 9 times out of 10 telling someone how to play a champ results in them waiting for you to die so they can go "LET ME TEACH U HOW TO PLAY YOUR CHAMP SCRUB" or a response along the lines of "IK how to play this champ you fucking scrub dont fucking tell me what to do"

I've had games like that too, the trick is to phrase your advice as passively as possible. People are quick to take it personally even if you are nice about it, so the only ways to deal with it are 'offering knowledge' while assuring them that you don't doubt them (I've lied plenty of times to pull this off) or just mute them.
That never works tbh

TBH it does. I've seen it. And if it doesn't then don't waste your time trash talking your teammates. You stand a better chance of winning if you shut up and play. If you harass your teammates you just run the risk of tilting them and making them feed worse.

Rarely. 9/10 I don't see change when someone is given advice. Usually people don't acknowledge it and continue whatever.

And I wasn't condoning being toxic, though I do feel being toxic is defined alot more loosely then most the carebears around here.

You want a definition?

Toxicity: the act of behaving in a manner which detracts from the fun of playing for other players. So much so that it actually makes them feel worse. There are may forms of toxicity:
-- Bitching at teammates and playing the blame-game.
-- Verbally abusing another player, or insulting them.
-- Goading another player into a rage. (including BM used for this intent)
-- Intentionally feeding the enemy or going afk and taking the decision to fight for a win away from your teammates.
-- other behaviors not listed.

All of these behaviors are unacceptable. They take the fun out of the game, and they create harmful and unnecessary stress for our fellow players.
This has never worked for me. Honestly, being toxic has been more effective. Not that I'm condoning it, just statistically, for me, being harsher tends to make people listen and do better.
There's a difference between being harsh and being toxic. Abusive and hurtful phrasing is toxic. Abuse is not necessary in order to communicate to somebody that they messed up and should do better.
Its not, but as I said, it seems to be more effective and if I want to win I have to use the most effective method.
I stated in an earlier comment that, more often than not, abusing teammates just tilts them more and makes them play worse.
I stated in an earlier comment that for me its the opposite.

I'm calling BS. What evidence do you have?

EDIT: Nevermind. Your argument is moot.  All of these behaviors are unacceptable. They take the fun out of the game, and they create harmful and unnecessary stress for our fellow players. You should not engage in them period. I guarantee that the majority of players would agree with this statement.
Yeah, I dont think anyone should. But if I have to tell Riven to stop feeding to win, well ...

"Riven, stop feeding. If they get more kills then we will fall further behind." There you go, a completely toxicity-free way to communicate that point.

However it usually helps to specify some techniques to avoid feeding, for example:

"Riven, please let our tank initiate the fight instead of you, they can draw enemy attention so you do not die so easily in the fight."

"Riven, please ward before you push that lane alone. If you can see the enemy coming you will have the option to escape before they catch you."

It's not that hard really. Your teammate might be on tilt and need the pointers. They might be too upset/tired to think of these things on their own. This can even turn their bad game around, so long as your statements are to the point, and without harassing / blaming.

Because the same technology that runs the chat filter runs the automated systems that flag toxic behavior.  It's simple.  Chat monitoring - flag behavior, review by human, punishment.

Intentional feeding, etc. are much harder to detect through automation and necessarily rely on reports.  Reports take time to reach critical mass.

Looks at youtube to see if there's a new "League of children" video.
What is league of children?

League of Children is two types of videos. 

There are videos by the channels owner, DiscoHeat (spelled backwards now, taeHocsiD), where they try some off meta thing, show it works in a few games. In the same video, he shows people who refuse to believe it can work and instantly decide to troll/rage/feed if he doesn't play the game their way (aka, they act like children).

The second type of video is where he takes clips of other streamers/YouTubers who act like children. There is no voice over, just the occasional flash back to earlier in the video to prove they're wrong.

Although more and more often it's him playing off meta, but either acting in such as way as to instigate toxic behavior from his team without being overtly toxic, or he's playing an off meta pick that can get a good KDA, but has very little to offer his team which results in losses.

(Not defending toxic behavior, but I do also think that trying to piss off your teammates in a ranked game to get some content for your youtube channel is pretty unethical)
